When I purchased Stronghold HD, Stronghold Crusader HD came bundled with it and since I loved the original (my review of Stronghold HD can be found  here ), I had high hopes of it. The original was a great and unique combination of a castle/city builder and siege-simulator and this game is no different, basically the same game all over again, except that it's not that great anymore. The game feels like an expansion to the original game and not a sequel, mostly because it uses shamelessly everything from Stronghold HD, which wouldn't necessarily be a problem, but it  remains inferior to the original in almost every aspect .   The milieu is the (not so) vast deserts of the Middle East in the Holy Land mostly during the Third Crusade. The so called historical campaigns are separated from each other and seem rather inconsistent, so there's hardly a plot which makes the single player game unsatisfying. The skirmish missions are even less entertaining, so those don't help the game either. There's also an expansion called Stronghold Crusader Extreme HD, which is super disappointing and all it does that it allows the player to set custom games (which we can do in the main game as well) under extreme conditions and fight multiple opponents at the same time who tend to start with more resources than us... I managed to beat 2 at the same time, but it was a very poor experience, reminding me of old-school 'real-time strategy' games that functioned like meat grinders, where you train more and more troops and just unleash them on your enemies. Some 'strategy'...  The main difference between the original game and this one is mainly the environment: instead of the beautiful English forestry, we get to play in deserts. It makes the game harder because now anything can catch fire and that introduces the only (!) new building (the other new one is basically a tent): the well. Yes, we can only put out the randomly appearing fires using wells (or instead of several small ones just one big well). Of course the wells also require workforce, so it is vital to have a few extra peasants. Naturally wells can't prevent the occurrence of fires, so the building on fire is going to take damage and if it's the armoury full of weapons... well, we're in trouble. The other factor is the oasis, which is the only suitable area we can build food production buildings on and needless to say, their size is quite limited. At least the oasis makes the game harder in a good way (requiring careful planning), as opposed to the random fire occurrences.  In a few missions we can play the Muslim side, but these are commando missions (can't train units, have to make do with the given ones) only, so we can forget about larger sieges, the main strength of Stronghold. Of course there is sense in the Muslims having no buildings: they should look different than the ones the crusaders have... By the way the crusaders do have Middle-Eastern looking buildings which is a bit strange, but at this point it's really just one of the smaller problems.  There are Arabian soldiers, mercenaries we can hire from the previously mentioned tents, for gold (instead of resources). This is an interesting formula as it can speed up the process of training quite a bit, but again, it can turn the game into grindfests at the expense of sieges. The new soldiers are fun (the slingers are fast and cheap but are weak and can attack at short range, the horse archers have great range and are very fast, but expensive and not as accurate as the normal archers), but they are mostly reused versions of the already existing units with readjusted strengths, except slaves (super cheap and weak units who can set buildings on fire) and the assassins (can climb walls and open castle gates). The assassin does have potential and can make a siege more interesting and a bit easier for the attacker. There's also a new fire ballista, a perfect tool for decimating defending archers on towers and it's also a welcome addtion to the attacking side.  Some issues that were in the original are also present here: the transparency of the buildings is still a problem when rotating the map and trying to rebuild certain sections of the castle wall and the lack of hotkeys is fatal in the fast paced matches when trying to vanquish multiple opponents. The voices of the peasants are still provided by the same person, which was fun at frist, in Stronghold HD, but this time it's obviously budget related.  Stronghold Crusader HD is obviously a letdown, not mainly because it feels like an expansion, but because it seems like a rather cheap duplicate of the great original. The new setting with all its accessories is a setback and the developer must have also felt the absence of the evil characters of the first game, because in the last mission we can meet them again (don't ask). Accordingly I can't recommend Stronghold Crusader HD to anyone: not to newcomers and especially not to fans of the original. If you want to experience a good siege just load up Stronghold HD again.   PROS + some useful additions and readjustments to the game + last mission is challenging  CONS - less emphasis on castle sieges - issues from the original are still present - campaign is not as enjoyable as the one in the original - feels like an expansion rather than a sequel - cheap ways to make the game harder  RATING 2/10

Stronghold Crusader is a somewhat obscure RTS designed around maintaining an efficient economy while also defeating an opponent in the traditional RTS sense. Peasants are the lifeblood of your castle as you struggle to feed them, keep them happy, and tax every last cent out of them in order to turn them into soldiers.   As the page says, it is a castle simulator, meaning you run a castle economy, can build castle walls in designs that are only limited by the imagination, and lay siege to your opponent's castles with trebuchets, rams, ballista, and catapults (and more).  The skirmish mode, map editor and Crusader Trail (50+ skirmish scenarios) highly enhance the replayability of this game. The AI comes in many flavors from the annoying and vindictive Caliph, to the overwhelming force of the combat loving Lionheart, or the 'Zerg Rush' of the Abbot and his massed monks. Each AI adds a different level of challenge, and learning to take them all on is quite fun.  Despite being an older game, multiplayer can be accomplished with a tool such as Gameranger, and the multiplayer works quite well.   Overall I highly suggest any RTS lover to pick up Stronghold Crusader HD, it is quite a fun experience that no current game quite manages to capture.  11/10 'Not too much water' -IGN

Ah, Stronghold Crusader. I remember this game when I was maybe......6? This game really brings back memories with the floppy disk games. Anyway lets review! Note: Buying the game will also include Stronghold Crusader Extreme but that is so terrible so I wont review it.  THE GAME Stronghold Crusader HD is a castle sim with I think 4 modes. Career/Story: Really just a set of tutorials and starting battles to get you ready to play the all grand skirmish mode(I think thats what its called) but never the less it can be fun but only sometimes.  Skirmish/Battle: This is probably what makes this game grand. It puts you in a screen where you decide things like the map, how many players fight, where they fight, difficulty, starting money, etc. Then you start building a castle and an army to help you crush the other players while not getting recked yourself. THIS IS WHAT YOU GET THE GAME FOR. I bet it would be fun in MP but none of my friends have it :(  Castle Builder- Just the mode if you want to build a huge castle, no enemies just you, your people, and that annoying flippin guide. (WHY?)  Multiplayer- If someone wants to add me to play this mode please do ;_;  AUDIO The game has solid voice acting from every character and they talk to you at the right times sometimes indicating how you should prepare, like telling you 'youre kingdom will get crushed' could indicating that they're lanuching an assault at you. The fighting audio is good but the people getting hit by arrows sounds like there coughing and screaming. Your castle based on how many people actually work it gets more or less chattery and theres less sounds of nature. The only REALLY bad voice acting is your guide, he doesnt change his accent when you change to like a british guy and his voice is just annoying but funny to abuse sometimes. Audio-8/10  GAMEPLAY Well as I explained in the modes section you are usually fighting other players, but most of the time youre trying to get people in your kingdom and keep them in your kingdom by maintaning food, taxes, and atractions for your people (like a dancing bear strapped to a pole wtf). Gameplay 9/10  STORYLINE I really dont think i should rate this but I will. The game yes has a story mode but it's mostly a tutorial with basic battles. The games story really comes mostly from the gameplay. Think of games like dota 2, CSGO, and TF2 mostly the story comes out of what you do and see, not whats told. Storyline 7/10  Graphics The graphics would obvioulsy be outdated for a game as old as this but you can see whats going on and not feel like you cant see what that means or indicates. Pretty solid graphics if you look at its age. Im gonna count the score as if I was rating this in the year this was released. Graphics 10/10  AI  Since this is what most people have to play with ill make a section for it. As I stated in audio the AI will give you hints about whats about to happen but it might not always happen, making them pretty clever enemies. Each king has a different tactic. Some build the castle a lot others go and start buiding an army, and some also try to build up they're economy so they could buy troops late game. But each kind changes his tactic depending on what he sees so the AI is different every time. It could use polishing sometimes though. AI 9/10  REPLAYABILITY As I just said the AI's tactic always changes so you never have the same game twice. Also there are TONS of different maps. By tons I mean like 30 maps each ranging on how many maximum players there can be and I think you are able to get more maps (IDK though). Replayability 10/10  VERDICT Stronghold Crusader's 10$ price tag is well worth it for such and old and polished game like this. FINAL RATING: 8.6/10

Pros:  -Stronghold perfected -In depth economic system -Rebalanced religion and ale mechanics (religion is no longer wildly overpriced for the benefit given) -Multitudes of new units, including arabic units that need only gold, and monks that can be trained at the cathedral -Wide variety of maps and play scenarios -Challenging, fun campaign mode -Computer opponents are widely varied, memorable, and fun to fight -Active online community -Massive replayability   Cons:  -No plot; campaign is just premade skirmishes -No fast-forward option   Overall:  This is it. This is the best stronghold game. Everything after, while sometimes good, failed to measure up. And Stronghold 1, while perfectly fine, didn't have the added depth this game has. While this game lacks a proper story mode, it focuses on what there really is to love about this game - the gameplay. There's a main campaign which consists of 50 skirmish matches against progressively harder scenarios, and another 20 in the 'expansion' that comes included with the HD version.  There are a multitude of different computer opponents to fight as well, and they can range from comically inept to frighteningly capable. Maps have a wide range of setups, from the vanilla 'everyone starts with the same basic setup and resources' to the maps which have no farmable land, to the maps that give one player every resource and all the others very few at all. The game is fun, and there are so many different ways to play that it will continue to challenge and entertain you.  One of the only real downsides is that there are still times when you watch and wait as your economy chugs along and your opponent builds his army, and there's just nothing for you to do but wait. Firefly did a good job of reducing that so it isn't as stark and noticeable as it was in Stronghold 1, but it still happens. A fast forward option would have been nice. Even more so if you like using swordsmen in sieges - you will legit wait five to ten minutes for them to get from your stronghold to the other guy's stronghold. Still, this is a very minor complaint in an otherwise flawless game.  There's a strong online community creating more maps and scenarios that can be downloaded and played. The addition of the arabic units with all their unique traits gives Crusader even more depth than before, and really just rounds out an already fantastic game. This is one of those games I've kept coming back to over the years, and probably will continue to do so for another decade.   Bottom Line:  Absolute recommend

This is more of a notes review for those who have played RTS games and enjoy them, on the more prominent differences A special RTS this and the series are. Buildings and Units are made instantly, but resources take time to come in. If you come from AoE series or similar then you may have a hard time grasping it initially. There is a pop limit, but not one so to speak, its not a worry at all. You don't create villagers, you have peasants, and you have a popularity to maintain and which can be influenced positively and negatively by a variety of things. Resources are based on a chain, both individually and overall. Eg Wheat Farms take time to plant the wheat, grow it, and harvest it. THats and individual production. Then the wheat must go through a Mill and a Bakery, then to the Granary for the bread to be used. I automatically think the Anno series if i would compare the economic chain too. THe amount of resource income you have is totally dependent on how much resources there are and how wisely you use the space. No assigning 20 villagers to 1 stone deposit. More like 10 Quarries which take 3 peasants each to run. Stronghold Crusader is known mostly for its 50 mission Skirmish Trail, with just a Campaign based on historic events as more of a bonus feature. And another 20-30 Skirmishes in the Warchest. I for one love this, as SHC is just made for deathmatches of all sorts. Theres a couple hand fulls of opponents, each with a personality, castle build, unit selection, all which creates their difficulty. There is no selective difficulty. Note that the game and opponents is relatively easy, its the context in which you play that gives mission difficulty, as you will find out playing the Skirmish Trail.  It really is a fun game and one you will remember. It has a special place in my heart.  Remember there is also websites and YT channels and videos (im slowly working on some myself) with walkthroughs and mission help, as quite often people need it!  Worth $15, and on sale, an absolute steal.

This game is perhaps overlooked by most people these days, considering there are others out there, like StarCraft, Age of Empires, Civilization, and plenty of lesser known RTS games.  Yet, this game has a certain charm to it that I think can't be found anywhere else. It's set in the Arabic desert, where you must fight for survival by mastering as many factors as you can, including some staple RTS features, like economics, resources, troops, and workers. This game also features two main ways to determine whether you succeed or not. This comes in the form of managing how much gold you have to buy troops, and how much food you have collected. Running out of food will cause your castle to start losing happiness, and people will begin to leave if it gets below halfway.  Since the food plays a major role in your economy, lacking it presents a severe problem of unbalanced gameplay; people won't be able to keep your economy going if they leave, which means that, if you don't have enough gold to buy food, you're basically doomed. You can't buy troops since you don't have gold, and if, by some chance, you happen to be out of other supplies, it's best to give up if you don't have any allies. Even then, the allies aren't guaranteed to help you, especially if they're A.I players.  This is where the unbalanced issue comes into place, because not everyone is good at managing their economy, and pitting people with little to no sense of economics against people who do know means that the latter are going to win. Every single time.   This is still a great game, though. If you are willing to learn how to manage economics, I recommend this game.
